I would put up 
createVehicle()
or something like that in the
setUp()

Once we have a veicle you can do whatever you want with it. The order 
does not matter.

I used to test create EJB, modify, save, delete and find EJBs. So 
used to resort to the above solution. I never cared about the order 
of execution.

- Nilesh

--- In junit@y..., scott.marshall@w... wrote:
> I'm currently developing JUnitEE for use with a J2EE application, 
and admit to being relatively new to J2EE and JUnit. However, I am 
getting problems running test suites as the order of execution does 
not appear to be constant. 
> Tests are written in this order : 
> testGetVehicle() 
> testAddVehicle() 
> testSaveVehicle() 
> testDeleteVehicle() 
> 
> Overall flow is to retrieve an entity, modify it, then delete it. 
> 
> Tests appear to be executed in this order : 
> testDeleteVehicle() 
> testGetVehicle() 
> testAddVehicle() 
> testSaveVehicle() 
> 
> By running out of order the testDeleteVehicle() method cant find 
the modified entity, and fails its test. 
> 
> Using JBuilder 6, is this related to most recent changes and 
compilation ? JUnitEE itself appears to be working fine. Any pointers 
of where to look ? 
> 
> Thanks 
> 
> Scott 
> 
>
